parts:
We Believe in Israel
@WeBelieveIsrael
A Very British Reckoning: Parliament, Palestine Action, and the Limits of Indulgence



What a curious thing the British Parliament is. A place of ceremony, decency, and the occasional fit of glorious indignation. It is where Prime Ministers rise and fall, where backbenchers mutter rebellions into their sleeves, and where—every now and then—truth finds itself tucked into the folds of Hansard.
Today, the House of Commons will consider a rather grave and sobering proposition: whether to proscribe Palestine Action as a terrorist organisation under the Terrorism Act 2000. On the surface, one might assume this to be a straightforward matter. Here is a group that breaks into private property, daubs blood-red paint on Jewish-owned businesses, celebrates the atrocities of October 7 with thinly veiled delight, and declares open alignment with Hamas—a proscribed terror group known, lest we forget, not for its healthcare policy or musical output, but for its penchant for abduction, murder, and genocidal rhetoric.
And yet. We are in Britain, dear reader, where things are rarely so simple.
To some, Palestine Action are plucky idealists—Glastonbury radicals in keffiyehs, throwing paint at factories in the name of justice. They are lionised by a certain ideological set as truth-tellers, disruptors, conscience-prickers. A few even mutter that their targets deserve it—that companies supplying defensive equipment to Israel are, by some grotesque logic, legitimate marks.
Here lies the first tragedy: the degradation of language. Protest, once a noble exercise in persuasion and conscience, has become performance art laced with menace. Speech is replaced by slogans, action by arson, argument by graffiti. And so we have Palestine Action—an organisation whose raison d’être is not to engage, debate, or reform, but to intimidate, disrupt, and destroy.
It was precisely this reality that We Believe in Israel (WBII) sought to lay bare.
While others tiptoed, equivocated, or quietly hoped the group would go away, WBII rolled up its sleeves. It gathered data, recorded incidents, traced links to Hamas and other extremist groups, and produced a series of meticulous briefings. These were not polemics, but evidentiary roadmaps. They documented the ideological radicalisation of Palestine Action, the coordinated nature of its operations, and the increasing violence of its tactics.
Those briefings landed on the desks of MPs, advisers, and ministers. They did not pander or exaggerate. They persuaded. It is no exaggeration to say that without WBII’s intervention, the Home Office might still be wringing its hands. Instead, we now stand at the precipice of a decision that will define how seriously this country treats domestic extremism in the age of antizionist activism.
Because make no mistake: what we are dealing with here is not mere protest against Israeli policy. We are witnessing a mutation of antizionism—once the preserve of political theorists and UN resolutions—into something more rabid, more primal. A hatred that doesn’t stop at Netanyahu or Gaza, but spills into school playgrounds, kosher restaurants, synagogues, and now factory floors.
It is the ideology that says Jews must apologise for Israel, that Jewish businesses are valid targets, and that violence is justifiable when wrapped in the flag of Palestine. The grotesque irony, of course, is that such thinking doesn’t help a single Palestinian child. It doesn’t build schools, it doesn’t create peace, and it certainly doesn’t bring about coexistence. What it does is import a foreign conflict onto British streets and cast the Jewish community as fair game.
Palestine Action has, through its own rhetoric and deeds, made its allegiances clear. And in so doing, it has made the case for its own proscription. Today’s vote in the Commons is more than a legal formality—it is a moral barometer.
To those who may yet oppose it, I ask: what more do you require? Does the open praise of Hamas not raise your hackles? Does the coordinated sabotage of legal businesses not offend your sense of order? Or have we sunk so far into cultural relativism that even terrorism can now be excused if the slogans are sufficiently poetic?
Some will surely vote against the motion. Perhaps they’ll quote Orwell. Or Gandhi. Or post a photo of Banksy. But history will remember that, when confronted with rising extremism, Parliament was offered a clear choice. And some chose to look away.
We must also recognise the role of integrity. At a time when far too many in public life shrink from difficult conversations, Lord Walney —the Government’s former independent adviser on political violence—has stood out as a man of principle and moral clarity. He has supported this cause from the beginning, not out of political convenience, but because he understands the stakes. His commitment to confronting the twin threats of rising extremism and democratic decay is an example many would do well to follow. Without his voice, and without his resolve, today’s debate might not have even reached the chamber.
In a saner world, WBII would be receiving public honours for its efforts. That it is instead met with defamation and abuse tells you much about the cultural moment we inhabit. But let us be clear: it was WBII’s research, WBII’s briefings, and WBII’s moral courage, supported by figures like Lord Walney, that helped push this decision across the line. And those who value democratic norms, public safety, and the rule of law owe them a debt.
For all the cynicism in politics, this is one of those rare days when principle might just prevail. And if it does, it will be thanks to those who refused to look the other way, even when it was inconvenient or unfashionable to speak up.
After all, that too is very British.
By Catherine Perez-Shakdam  - Executive Director We Believe In Israel

Certainly—here is a **critical, fact-based assessment** of the above statement by Catherine Perez-Shakdam (We Believe in Israel, WBII) on the campaign to proscribe Palestine Action as a terrorist group in the UK. I will address:

1. **Factual accuracy of claims about Palestine Action**
2. **Assessment of the rhetoric and reasoning**
3. **Discussion of broader implications and potential biases**

---

## 1. **Factual Accuracy of Claims about Palestine Action**

### **a) “Breaks into private property, daubs blood-red paint on Jewish-owned businesses, celebrates the atrocities of October 7, declares open alignment with Hamas.”**

- **Breaking into Property and Paint Sabotage:**  
  *True in substance.*  
  Palestine Action is a direct-action protest group in the UK, known for targeting premises associated with Elbit Systems (an Israeli arms manufacturer) and companies supplying arms to Israel. Their methods include breaking into properties, occupying factory roofs, daubing red paint, and causing property damage. These acts have resulted in numerous arrests and criminal prosecutions, mostly for criminal damage and aggravated trespass【web†1】.

- **Targeting Jewish-Owned Businesses:**  
  *Misleading, with a degree of exaggeration.*  
  The group targets businesses linked to Israel’s defense industry, notably Elbit. Many such companies are not “Jewish-owned” per se; describing them as such risks conflating criticism of Israeli state-linked companies with targeting Jews as an ethnic/religious group. There is **no substantial public evidence** that Palestine Action specifically targets businesses solely for being Jewish-owned; their stated objective is disruption of the arms trade with Israel.

- **Celebrating the Atrocities of October 7 / Open Alignment with Hamas:**  
  *Requires evidence; likely exaggerated or tendentious.*  
  There have been accusations—especially in pro-Israel media—that members or supporters of Palestine Action have shown support for Hamas or justified violence. However, *to date, there is no clear, official Palestine Action statement that explicitly celebrates the October 7 attacks or pledges allegiance to Hamas*. The group’s rhetoric is militant and provocative, but actual “open alignment” (i.e., declared allegiance or operational coordination) with Hamas is a **serious legal charge** and requires robust evidence. British law enforcement and the Home Office will have reviewed classified and open-source intelligence for the parliamentary motion, but this is not public.

- **Incitement and Antisemitism:**  
  *Partial truth, but not conclusively established as organizational doctrine.*  
  Some protests and slogans from far-left and anti-Zionist groups have crossed into antisemitic tropes. It is, however, inaccurate to say that Palestine Action as an organization has an official doctrine of targeting Jews as Jews. The group itself claims to be anti-Zionist, not antisemitic—a crucial distinction in law and in public debate.

---

### **b) “WBII rolled up its sleeves … traced links to Hamas and other extremist groups, produced meticulous briefings … documented ideological radicalisation … increasing violence.”**

- **WBII Research and Briefings:**  
  *Plausible, but should be scrutinized for bias.*  
  WBII is an advocacy group with a strong pro-Israel stance. While it may have produced evidence-based briefings, its framing is explicitly adversarial. It is correct that groups like WBII and others have lobbied the UK government for proscription and provided dossiers to MPs. Whether these briefings meet the standards of independent, legal, and evidentiary neutrality is debatable.

- **Increasing Violence:**  
  *Partially true, but context needed.*  
  Palestine Action’s tactics have escalated in terms of direct action and property damage, but have not (as of July 2024) resulted in fatalities or mass-casualty violence. The threshold for “terrorism” in UK law includes serious violence against people, not just property, *unless property damage is intended to intimidate or coerce a population*. There is a **live debate** as to whether Palestine Action’s activities cross that threshold.

---

### **c) “Import a foreign conflict onto British streets … ideology that says Jews must apologise for Israel … Jewish businesses are valid targets … violence justifiable in the name of Palestine.”**

- **Importation of Conflict:**  
  *True as a sociopolitical observation.*  
  The Israel-Palestine conflict is indeed a polarizing issue in the UK, as seen in mass demonstrations, counter-demonstrations, and increases in reported hate crimes (both antisemitic and Islamophobic) following the outbreak of hostilities.

- **Conflation of Anti-Zionism with Antisemitism:**  
  *Oversimplified.*  
  Some anti-Zionist activism is antisemitic, but much is not. Legal and academic authorities—including the UK government—distinguish between criticism of Israel/Zionism and antisemitism, though the boundary is debated and sometimes crossed in practice.

---

### **d) “Palestine Action … made its allegiances clear. … Today’s vote … is a moral barometer.”**

- **Clear Allegiances:**  
  *Unsubstantiated in law unless proven.*  
  If the group is shown in court or via credible public evidence to coordinate with Hamas or proscribed terrorist entities, proscription would be legally warranted. However, being “radical” or “destructive” does not, by itself, equate to terrorism.

- **Moral Barometer:**  
  *Subjective framing.*  
  The statement asserts that the vote is a test of Britain’s moral fiber; this is an advocacy position, not a matter of fact.

---

## 2. **Assessment of Rhetoric and Reasoning**

The article is written in a **rhetorically forceful, polemical style**:

- **Loaded Language:** “daubs blood-red paint on Jewish-owned businesses,” “celebrates atrocities,” “alignment with Hamas,” “mutation of antizionism … more rabid, more primal,” “violence justifiable when wrapped in the flag of Palestine.”
    - These are strong, emotive terms designed to evoke moral outrage.

- **Framing and Appeal to Britishness:** The text appeals to British traditions, the moral responsibility of Parliament, and the principle of public safety—common tropes in political advocacy.

- **Ad Hominem and Generalization Risks:** There is a risk of conflating all anti-Israel protest with extremism or antisemitism, and of painting Palestine Action with a single brush.

- **Use of Authority Figures:** The article cites Lord Walney and the work of WBII as examples of “moral clarity,” aiming to add legitimacy.

---

## 3. **Broader Implications and Bias**

- **Advocacy and Evidence:**  
  WBII is not a neutral observer; it is a pro-Israel advocacy group. This does not invalidate its evidence but necessitates *critical scrutiny* of its framing and claims.

- **Legal and Societal Thresholds:**  
  The UK’s Terrorism Act 2000 defines terrorism in ways that may or may not fit Palestine Action, depending on whether the group’s activities are proven (in law) to be designed to intimidate or coerce for political ends, especially if linked to violent groups abroad.

- **Risk of Overreach:**  
  Proscription is a draconian step, criminalizing membership, support, or even public statements in favor of the group. If applied to direct-action protest groups without clear evidence of intent to harm people, there is a risk to civil liberties and the right to protest. The historical record shows that overbroad use of terrorism laws has had chilling effects on activism of all kinds.

- **The Danger of Conflation:**  
  Conflating criticism of Israel or even militant anti-Zionism with terrorism/antisemitism can undermine both anti-racism efforts and the credibility of counter-extremism policy.

---

## **Conclusion**

**Summary Judgment:**
- The article accurately describes the disruptive, often criminal tactics of Palestine Action and the legal debate around its activities.
- It overreaches in its conflation of anti-Zionism with antisemitism and with terrorism, at least without robust and public evidence.
- Claims of “open alignment” with Hamas are not substantiated in the public domain and would need to be proven in law.
- The rhetoric is polemical and advocacy-driven, not neutral reporting.

**Forward-Thinking Note:**
- If Parliament proscribes Palestine Action, it will set a precedent for the criminalization of militant direct action—potentially including groups on the far-right or far-left. This raises legitimate concerns about proportionality, civil liberties, and the boundaries of protest.
- The decision should rest on hard evidence, not only on the force of rhetoric or political expediency.

**Recommendation:**
- Scrutinize both the evidence provided by WBII and the official reasoning presented to Parliament.
- Be wary of rhetorical escalation and ensure civil liberties are not unduly curtailed in the name of counter-extremism, lest the cure become worse than the disease.

---

**References:**
- [BBC News coverage of Palestine Action](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-66886230)
- [UK Home Office guidance on proscription](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/proscribed-terror-groups-or-organisations--2)
- [Palestine Action official statements](https://palestineaction.org/)
- [Jewish Chronicle, Guardian, Independent articles on the debate]
